import datetime as dt import pandas as pd import os for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'): for filename in filenames: print(os.path.join(dirname, filename)) In this notebook we are going to compare the top Auto EDA libraries that really facilite the dataset analysis and visualziation! The main idea is that you can compare time to plot and results of each AutoEda library so you can select the best for your work. #

1. 📊 Dataprep 📚

!pip install dataprep from dataprep.eda import plot, plot_correlation, create_report, plot_missing df = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/titanic/train.csv') # Start of Pandas Profiling process start_time = dt.datetime.now() print("Started at ", start_time) plot(df) create_report(df) plot(df, "Age") plot(df, "Age", "Embarked") print('Dataprep finished!!') finish_time = dt.datetime.now() print("Finished at ", finish_time) elapsed = finish_time - start_time print("Elapsed time: ", elapsed) #

2. 📊 AutoViz 📚

AutoViz stands out of the crowd of freeware Pythonic Rapid EDA Automation tools, doing things in a very fast way, the way better than its close freeware rivals like SweetViz or Pandas Profiling !pip install git+git://github.com/AutoViML/AutoViz.git !pip install xlrd # Start of AutoViz process start_time = dt.datetime.now() print("Started at ", start_time) df = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/creditcardfraud/creditcard.csv') df.head() from autoviz.AutoViz_Class import AutoViz_Class AV = AutoViz_Class() dftc = AV.AutoViz( filename='', sep='' , depVar='Class', dfte=df, header=0, verbose=1, lowess=False, chart_format='png', max_rows_analyzed=300000, max_cols_analyzed=30 ) print('AutoViz finished!!') finish_time = dt.datetime.now() print("Finished at ", finish_time) elapsed = finish_time - start_time print("Elapsed time: ", elapsed) #

3. 📊 Pandas Profiling 📚

from pandas_profiling import ProfileReport df = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/credit-card-customers/BankChurners.csv') # Start of Pandas Profiling process start_time = dt.datetime.now() print("Started at ", start_time) report = ProfileReport(df) report print('Pandas Profling finished!!') finish_time = dt.datetime.now() print("Finished at ", finish_time) elapsed = finish_time - start_time print("Elapsed time: ", elapsed) #

4. 📊 SweetViz 📚

!pip install sweetviz import sweetviz as sv # Start of Pandas Profiling process start_time = dt.datetime.now() print("Started at ", start_time) df = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/credit-card-customers/BankChurners.csv').head(2000) advert_report = sv.analyze([df, 'Data']) advert_report.show_html() ![sweetviz.gif](attachment:sweetviz.gif) print('SweetViz finished!!') finish_time = dt.datetime.now() print("Finished at ", finish_time) elapsed = finish_time - start_time print("Elapsed time: ", elapsed) #

5. 📊 Lux 📚

!pip install lux-api import lux import pandas as pd df = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/titanic/train.csv') df #

6. 📊 D-Tale 📚

! pip install dtale # References The references to the blog posts below may be helpful in your deeper delve into the universe of AutoViz * Pandas Profiling GitHub - https://github.com/pandas-profiling/pandas-profiling * Dan Roth, AutoViz: A New Tool for Automated Visualization - https://towardsdatascience.com/autoviz-a-new-tool-for-automated-visualization-ec9c1744a6ad * George Vyshnya, PROs and CONs of Rapid EDA Tools - https://medium.com/sbc-group-blog/pros-and-cons-of-rapid-eda-tools-e1ccd159ab07 * SweetViz - https://towardsdatascience.com/sweetviz-automated-eda-in-python-a97e4cabacde * DataPrep - https://sfu-db.github.io/dataprep/user_guide/eda/plot.html

import datetime as dt
import pandas as pd 
 import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename)) 
 !pip install dataprep 
 from dataprep.eda import plot, plot_correlation, create_report, plot_missing 
 df = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/titanic/train.csv') 
 # Start of Pandas Profiling process
start_time = dt.datetime.now()
print("Started at ", start_time) 
 plot(df) 
 create_report(df) 
 plot(df, "Age") 
 plot(df, "Age", "Embarked") 
 print('Dataprep finished!!')
finish_time = dt.datetime.now()
print("Finished at ", finish_time)
elapsed = finish_time - start_time
print("Elapsed time: ", elapsed) 
 !pip install git+git://github.com/AutoViML/AutoViz.git
!pip install xlrd 
 # Start of AutoViz process
start_time = dt.datetime.now()
print("Started at ", start_time) 
 df = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/creditcardfraud/creditcard.csv')
df.head() 
 from autoviz.AutoViz_Class import AutoViz_Class

AV = AutoViz_Class()
dftc = AV.AutoViz(
    filename='', 
    sep='' , 
    depVar='Class', 
    dfte=df, 
    header=0, 
    verbose=1, 
    lowess=False, 
    chart_format='png', 
    max_rows_analyzed=300000, 
    max_cols_analyzed=30
) 
 print('AutoViz finished!!')
finish_time = dt.datetime.now()
print("Finished at ", finish_time)
elapsed = finish_time - start_time
print("Elapsed time: ", elapsed) 
 from pandas_profiling import ProfileReport 
 df = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/credit-card-customers/BankChurners.csv') 
 # Start of Pandas Profiling process
start_time = dt.datetime.now()
print("Started at ", start_time) 
 report = ProfileReport(df) 
 report 
 print('Pandas Profling finished!!')
finish_time = dt.datetime.now()
print("Finished at ", finish_time)
elapsed = finish_time - start_time
print("Elapsed time: ", elapsed) 
 !pip install sweetviz 
 import sweetviz as sv 
 # Start of Pandas Profiling process
start_time = dt.datetime.now()
print("Started at ", start_time) 
 df = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/credit-card-customers/BankChurners.csv').head(2000) 
 advert_report = sv.analyze([df, 'Data']) 
 advert_report.show_html() 
 print('SweetViz finished!!')
finish_time = dt.datetime.now()
print("Finished at ", finish_time)
elapsed = finish_time - start_time
print("Elapsed time: ", elapsed) 
 !pip install lux-api 
 import lux
import pandas as pd 
 df = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/titanic/train.csv') 
 df 
 ! pip install dtale

# References

The references to the blog posts below may be helpful in your deeper delve into the universe of AutoViz

* Pandas Profiling GitHub - https://github.com/pandas-profiling/pandas-profiling
* Dan Roth, AutoViz: A New Tool for Automated Visualization - https://towardsdatascience.com/autoviz-a-new-tool-for-automated-visualization-ec9c1744a6ad
* George Vyshnya, PROs and CONs of Rapid EDA Tools - https://medium.com/sbc-group-blog/pros-and-cons-of-rapid-eda-tools-e1ccd159ab07
* SweetViz - https://towardsdatascience.com/sweetviz-automated-eda-in-python-a97e4cabacde
* DataPrep - https://sfu-db.github.io/dataprep/user_guide/eda/plot.html

markdown_cells.source:
In this notebook we are going to compare the top Auto EDA libraries that really facilite the dataset analysis and visualziation!

The main idea is that you can compare time to plot and results of each AutoEda library so you can select the best for your work.

#

1. 📊 Dataprep 📚

#

2. 📊 AutoViz 📚

AutoViz stands out of the crowd of freeware Pythonic Rapid EDA Automation tools, doing things in a very fast way, the way better than its close freeware rivals like SweetViz or Pandas Profiling

#

3. 📊 Pandas Profiling 📚

#

4. 📊 SweetViz 📚

#

5. 📊 Lux 📚

#

6. 📊 D-Tale 📚

# References

The references to the blog posts below may be helpful in your deeper delve into the universe of AutoViz

* Pandas Profiling GitHub - https://github.com/pandas-profiling/pandas-profiling
* Dan Roth, AutoViz: A New Tool for Automated Visualization - https://towardsdatascience.com/autoviz-a-new-tool-for-automated-visualization-ec9c1744a6ad
* George Vyshnya, PROs and CONs of Rapid EDA Tools - https://medium.com/sbc-group-blog/pros-and-cons-of-rapid-eda-tools-e1ccd159ab07
* SweetViz - https://towardsdatascience.com/sweetviz-automated-eda-in-python-a97e4cabacde
* DataPrep - https://sfu-db.github.io/dataprep/user_guide/eda/plot.html
